awd_titl_txt: Freestanding and Permselective Graphene Oxide Membranes Assembled at Liquid/Liquid Interface through Novel "Stitch Chemistry"
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal Number: 1603264, PI: Zhu, Jiahua
Title: Chemically Stitching Graphene Oxide Nanosheets into Separation Membranes 

Purifying water from processing streams with low energy consumption is urgently needed in the chemical, petrochemical and bioengineering industries. In addition, conventional polymer- and ceramic-based membrane technologies have significant challenges in biofuel separations. Graphene oxide (GO, a sheet material with a thickness less than 1.0 nm) has been explored as a membrane material with great potential in water separations. The membrane would consist of layers of this sheet material. The proposed research will use novel "stitch" molecules as a tool to assemble GO sheets into a membrane with desired microstructure pattern and layer spacing. These membranes are designed to achieve permselective separation of water in a broad range of separation practices. The outcome of this research is to offer a transferrable freestanding membrane processing technology that is capable to revolutionize biofuel separation efficiency, and greatly improve water purification capability. The educational broader impacts are addressed through professional training of graduate students, development of graduate curriculum and promoted STEM education and engagement in focused outreach activities to pre-college students. 

This research focuses on the fundamental understanding of interfacial transport, reaction kinetics, and self-assembly phenomena of graphene oxide sheets into freestanding membranes at using polymerization chemistry facilitated by a liquid/liquid interface. The self assembly at the liquid/liquid interface will be enabled with the use of novel stitching molecules to impact the layer to layer spacing of the GO membrane, the formation of the membrane surface, and the surface chemistry of the pore channels. The research will use examples of biofuel separation and water purification applications to test the selectivity and permeability of the resultant membranes. The specific research goals are to: 1) understand the transport behavior and assembly phenomena of GO sheets into membranes at the liquid/liquid interface; 2) tune GO membrane pore microstructure and surface chemistry properties using reactive groups in the GO basal planes to impact the membrane's structure and chemical function; and 3) reveal the process-structure-property relationships of GO membranes targeting permselective biofuel separation and water purification applications. The transferability of this technology will enable its immediate dissemination to a wide range of separation applications.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Project outcomes

This award project aimed to study how graphene oxide (GO) based membranes to be utilized for both liquid and gas separation purposes, including understanding the transport behavior and assembly phenomena of GO nanosheets in to membranes, tuning the microstructure of GO membranes to improve the both stability and separation performance, and designing novel hybrid composite membranes with other 2-dimentional materials.

Intellectual merit

GO is a 2-dimentinoal nanosheet with thickness of single carbon atom theoretically. The unique 2-dimentional laminar structure, chemical and thermal stabilities, and easy functionalization make GO a promising membrane material. However, due to the intrinsic hydrophilic property of GO, the pure GO membrane suffers from its severe swelling issue in liquid separation. This award leads to a set of original discoveries, that solved the swelling issues of prepared GO membranes from different aspects, and excellent gas and liquid separation performances were achieved simultaneously. Firstly, from membrane fabrication aspect, we presented a facile method to fabricated GO/reduced GO hybrid membrane using ethylenediamine (EDA) as cross-linker. By simply applying a pre-cross-linking before membrane fabrication and controlling the reaction time, a stable GO/EDA membrane in water with narrow distance between neighboring nanosheets (d-spacing) was successfully fabricated. Secondly, from structure of GO membrane aspect, a GO-based membrane with reduced wrinkling structure, which was considered as one of the negative parameters for good separation performance, was generated. By using a novel modification method, GO nanosheets were stacked tightly because of stronger plane-plane connection was introduced, and led to less wrinkles formed during the assembling process. Thirdly, from the hybrid composite membrane aspect, we creatively combine another 2-D material, boron nitride (BN), with GO to fabricate a BNGO membrane. The BN played two roles here, membrane itself and cross-linker (improve the stability). After surface modification of both GO and BN nanosheets, two different 2-D materials were connected with covalent bonds. The prepared BNGO membrane exhibit compact laminar structure and small narrow d-spacing. At last, from the structure of original GO nanosheet aspect, we noticed that the original GO nanosheets with different lateral size had varied distribution of different functional groups, which was significant for understanding next step of surface modification and final membrane structure. Three sets of GO nanosheets were prepared by simple centrifugation method, and were used to fabricate membranes following the same protocol. It is interesting to find out that they show different separation performances under different operation conditions, like pH, surface charge, or size of separation targets. This work could be useful for guiding the selection of GO nanosheets for membrane fabrication towards various separation targets. In summary, this award solved the severe swelling issue of GO membrane from different aspects by controlling the surface chemistry of the GO nanosheets. Moreover, through understanding the surface chemistry of GO sheets, it would be helpful for developing other GO0-based structures and new applications.

Broader of impacts

The successful fabrication of BNGO membranes breaks out the limitation of pure GO membranes, which brings more possibilities in GO hybrid membrane. Moreover, the study about GO nanosheets have attracted tremendous attention of scientists around the world, such as GO-based membrane for separation, GO involved electrode materials for solar cells, batteries, and supercapacitors, and GO reinforced polymer composites for better mechanical strength, elasticity, and conductivity. This award accelerated the intellectual growth of PI and his students, who gained enormous experience in graphene and graphene related materials as well as the membrane fabrication techniques. All the students received valuable experience on experimental techniques in membrane fabrication, characterization, and evaluation in customized pervaporation separation and dead-end separation systems. To the date, the discoveries from this award had been transmitted to 5 publications on high quality journals, including Journal of Membrane Science, ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces, and Journal of Colloid and Interface Science. Besides the experiment, students on this award were also systematically trained through the oral presentations on AIChE meeting, Materials Science & Technology conference, and poster session of Engineering School of The University of Akron. One of the students who worked on this project won Outstanding Graduate Fellowship Research Award of Chemical, Biomolecular, and Corrosion Engineering of The University of Akron (only one winner for each grade per year). PI received the previous awards from professional societies including “2017 Early Career Investigator Award” from ECS Electrodeposition Division and 2017 “Early Career Award” from Polymer Processing Society.


Last Modified: 03/06/2022
Modified by: Jiahua Zhu
